items.title: üç∫ 12 Belgian Birthday Beers of 2024
items.content_html:
A little summary after working my way through 12 Belgian beers gifted to me for my birthday. Largely it’s been an enjoyable selection with just a couple of weak offerings. Mostly, these were all new to me. The Jupiler and Duvel I’ve seen everywhere but never tried and it’s easy to see why they’re popular. The St. Barnadus and Westmalle are real discoveries and I’m really happy to have found them - they’ll be reappearing in my future for sure!

# Beer

2 Brugse Zot Blond ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ

items.title: Southampton FC Report Card
items.content_html:
Southampton have a somewhat swollen squad this season after significant recruitment and failing to move on a few names that are really surplus to requirements. As we reach the second international break here’s a few notes after 6 games. ‚öΩ

Starting at the back Ramsdale has had a solid start. In a team that gives up so many chances and hasn’t won a game it’s hard to say if he’ll be worth points come the end of the season. McCarthy has had limited time and largely has been what we’d expect of him. Personally, I’d have been happy to take McCarthy in goal and spend ¬£20m+ on attacking talent - a more pressing need IMHO.

Sugawara was presumably signed on the assumption that KWP would leave. He didn’t. Yuki looks good so far but after a couple of recent mistakes (alongside our general defensive struggles) I’d be tempted to slot KWP back in for a while. KWP is a top-half right back and I’m not a fan of sticking him out left - it doesn’t get the best from him and unbalances us. Bree is also available here but he’s a clear third choice.

The centre of defence is two or three from Bednarek, THB and Stephens with Edwards, Wood and ABK as backup. Not seen much of the latter three but my preference (like most fans I suspect) is THB and Bednarek. There are mistakes in there but with time I think they can build a strong partnership. THB has done well since coming back in and should grow. Stephens is a reasonable third choice. Martin possibly over-values his leadership and fans under-state his qualities. He’s a perfectly fine CB for our level right now, but behind the other two. Edwards, ABK, and Wood aren’t really close to the first team right now.

If you exclude KWP we’re actually a bit light at left back. Taylor is my preference here at the moment. A balanced back four is important and he can give us that. Not the most attacking, but gives us what we need to get more solid and develop from there. I’ve never been a big fan of Manning (although he seemingly did well against Arsenal). With Larios not really close at the moment KWP is (reluctantly) the best reserve here with Manning behind him in the pecking order.

Our midfield is where the real headaches start and it only gets worse as you move forward. Whilst the back line isn’t that strong it’s at least relatively clear. I’m still not certain we’ve settled on our best midfield. That said, Downes is probably a clear choice. There’s a reason he dropped to the Championship but I think he’s got enough to step up and he’s mostly showing it. However, like others, he needs to cut the mistakes.

Fernandes has been really impressive. Still very young but I’m excited to see how he develops, I think he’s already next on the team sheet after Downes if Lallana isn’t available Adam’s minutes are being heavily managed but playing an hour in every four or five is possibly more disruptive than helpful. Ideally we’d get him on the pitch more.

Smallbone has been out for a while, I think he’s not quite at the level and will be useful depth but I’d be surprised to see him force a regular place. Aribo is a bit of an enigma. At his best he gives us something unique but he doesn’t always bring it. Ugochukwu has shown promise and inexperience in equal measure but is likely our best cover for Downes. How much we develop him before sending him back to Chelsea is an interesting question.

My preferred midfield three is Downes, Aribo and either Fernandes or Lallana. Not sure that’s ever going to set the world on fire!

If the midfield three is uninspiring the front three is genuinely worrying and why I’d have liked to have spent some of that Ramsdale fee elsewhere. The ray of light here is Dibling. He’s been excellent so far but still needs careful management. We shouldn’t be relying on an 18 year old kid but we are and we should play him whenever we can without risking him. We do have some depth on the right with Amo-Ameyaw and exciting prospect (if behind Dibling in his development) and Cornet a very capable backup. This is probably also Armstrong’s best position. Again, he didn’t really hit the Premier League running and at this point it feels like the Championship is his natural level.

The left side is a riddle that Martin is yet to solve. We’re really struggling here. Fraser might be the best answer we have, or more likely tohe only option. Sulemana seems to be permanently injured and has yet to show any evidence he can compete at this level. Diaz looks completely lost out there. If that’s his preferred position we should give up on him now. Personally, I think he’s best considered in the striker role.

That central position is a battle between Stewart, Brereton Diaz, Archer and Onuachu. A worryingly thin set of options. Archer is probably the best prospect, but it’s a lot to ask of the youngster. A great finish against Arsenal is indicative of the potential and we must hope like crazy he can find a run.

I feel for Stewart who seems cursed, but also doesn’t really look like the answer. He did well against Bournemouth but without any goal threat. Onuachu seems to be forcing his way into Martin’s thoughts and clearly knows his way to goal, can he do it at this level? I’m not sure.

Overall we’re about where many might have predicted. Too leaky at the back and without enough goal threat at the front. I don’t have a particular issue with the tactics or setup, but we must take more risks going forward and put more pressure on opposition defences. Keeping the ball the way we do is no threat to PL defences and opponents will just wait for our inevitable mistakes.

We’re capable of causing trouble when we move forward with more intent. Too early to panic and there has been a few shoots of promise, but we must improve our defensive stability and learn to be more incisive in transition.
items.content_text:
Southampton have a somewhat swollen squad this season after significant recruitment and failing to move on a few names that are really surplus to requirements. As we reach the second international break here's a few notes after 6 games. ‚öΩ


<!--more-->


Starting at the back Ramsdale has had a solid start. In a team that gives up so many chances and hasn't won a game it's hard to say if he'll be worth points come the end of the season. McCarthy has had limited time and largely has been what we'd expect of him. Personally, I'd have been happy to take McCarthy in goal and spend ¬£20m+ on attacking talent - a more pressing need IMHO.


Sugawara was presumably signed on the assumption that KWP would leave. He didn't. Yuki looks good so far but after a couple of recent mistakes (alongside our general defensive struggles) I'd be tempted to slot KWP back in for a while. KWP is a top-half right back and I'm not a fan of sticking him out left - it doesn't get the best from him and unbalances us. Bree is also available here but he's a clear third choice.


The centre of defence is two or three from Bednarek, THB and Stephens with Edwards, Wood and ABK as backup. Not seen much of the latter three but my preference (like most fans I suspect) is THB and Bednarek. There are mistakes in there but with time I think they can build a strong partnership. THB has done well since coming back in and should grow. Stephens is a reasonable third choice. Martin possibly over-values his leadership and fans under-state his qualities. He's a perfectly fine CB for our level right now, but behind the other two. Edwards, ABK, and Wood aren't really close to the first team right now.


If you exclude KWP we're actually a bit light at left back. Taylor is my preference here at the moment. A balanced back four is important and he can give us that. Not the most attacking, but gives us what we need to get more solid and develop from there. I've never been a big fan of Manning (although he seemingly did well against Arsenal). With Larios not really close at the moment KWP is (reluctantly) the best reserve here with Manning behind him in the pecking order.


Our midfield is where the real headaches start and it only gets worse as you move forward. Whilst the back line isn't that strong it's at least relatively clear. I'm still not certain we've settled on our best midfield. That said, Downes is probably a clear choice. There's a reason he dropped to the Championship but I think he's got enough to step up and he's mostly showing it. However, like others, he needs to cut the mistakes.


Fernandes has been really impressive. Still very young but I'm excited to see how he develops, I think he's already next on the team sheet after Downes if Lallana isn't available Adam's minutes are being heavily managed but playing an hour in every four or five is possibly more disruptive than helpful. Ideally we'd get him on the pitch more.


Smallbone has been out for a while, I think he's not quite at the level and will be useful depth but I'd be surprised to see him force a regular place. Aribo is a bit of an enigma. At his best he gives us something unique but he doesn't always bring it. Ugochukwu has shown promise and inexperience in equal measure but is likely our best cover for Downes. How much we develop him before sending him back to Chelsea is an interesting question.


My preferred midfield three is Downes, Aribo and either Fernandes or Lallana. Not sure that's ever going to set the world on fire!


If the midfield three is uninspiring the front three is genuinely worrying and why I'd have liked to have spent some of that Ramsdale fee elsewhere. The ray of light here is Dibling. He's been excellent so far but still needs careful management. We shouldn't be relying on an 18 year old kid but we are and we should play him whenever we can without risking him. We do have some depth on the right with Amo-Ameyaw and exciting prospect (if behind Dibling in his development) and Cornet a very capable backup. This is probably also Armstrong's best position. Again, he didn't really hit the Premier League running and at this point it feels like the Championship is his natural level.


The left side is a riddle that Martin is yet to solve. We're really struggling here. Fraser might be the best answer we have, or more likely tohe only option. Sulemana seems to be permanently injured and has yet to show any evidence he can compete at this level. Diaz looks completely lost out there. If that's his preferred position we should give up on him now. Personally, I think he's best considered in the striker role.


That central position is a battle between Stewart, Brereton Diaz, Archer and Onuachu. A worryingly thin set of options. Archer is probably the best prospect, but it's a lot to ask of the youngster. A great finish against Arsenal is indicative of the potential and we must hope like crazy he can find a run.


I feel for Stewart who seems cursed, but also doesn't really look like the answer. He did well against Bournemouth but without any goal threat. Onuachu seems to be forcing his way into Martin's thoughts and clearly knows his way to goal, can he do it at this level? I'm not sure.


Overall we're about where many might have predicted. Too leaky at the back and without enough goal threat at the front. I don't have a particular issue with the tactics or setup, but we must take more risks going forward and put more pressure on opposition defences. Keeping the ball the way we do is no threat to PL defences and opponents will just wait for our inevitable mistakes.


We're capable of causing trouble when we move forward with more intent. Too early to panic and there has been a few shoots of promise, but we must improve our defensive stability and learn to be more incisive in transition.

12-year-old Mully has lost his mother and discovers his debt-ridden father stealing the charity money they’ve raised in her name. Grabbing the cash, Mully steals a taxi and is shocked to find a woman, Joy, in the back seat with a baby. A straight-talking solicitor who didn’t expect to get pregnant, Joy is struggling with motherhood and planning to give her baby to a friend who will raise the child as her own. She joins Mully on a wild journey across Ireland, stealing cars, hitch-hiking, catching ferries and breaking police barricades.

items.content_html:
Taken from BBC News. I (perhaps incorrectly) infer a couple of key things:

  1. By drawing Tory votes Reform did much more to win the election for Labour than Labour did
  2. Increasing your vote share by 1.6% and getting 211 new seats shows just how fundamentally flawed the UK electoral system is

üó≥Ô∏è
items.content_text:
Taken from [BBC News.](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election/2024/uk/results) I (perhaps incorrectly) infer a couple of key things:

1. By drawing Tory votes Reform did much more to win the election for Labour than Labour did
1. Increasing your vote share by 1.6% and getting 211 new seats shows just how fundamentally flawed the UK electoral system is

üó≥Ô∏è

![Graph of change in vote share by party for the UK General Election 2024. Showing a small positive swing for Labour and a large reduction for the Conservative Party](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/bbc-ge-2024-vote-share.png)

items.content_html: In recent years we’ve tried to gift the girls experiences rather than things, they’ve so many things. So, we took the girls to Wembley Stadium last night for the first London night of the Eras Tour (Christmas ‘23 present). Whether you like the music or not it’s a cracking show and Taylor’s talent and acumen is undeniable. 88,500 people packed into Wembley is a sight to behold. First born provided me with a “Weigman is a Swiftie” bracelet, combining two of her loves. Last born cried tears of pure joy. Even my lovely wife had a great time. üéµ

items.content_html: My hometown of Southampton has a deep history, with the general area being inhabited for thousands of years. Large parts of the city’s 800+ year old walls remain and the area has an important maritime history. The Titanic and Spitfire stories loom heavy along with the impact of the Blitz.
items.content_text:
My **hometown** of [Southampton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southampton) has a deep history, with the general area being inhabited for thousands of years. Large parts of the city's 800+ year old walls remain and the area has an important maritime history. The [Titanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titanic) and [Spitfire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermarine_Spitfire) stories loom heavy along with the impact of the [Blitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southampton_Blitz).

![The spire of St Michael's church, Southampton, viewed from Western Esplanade through a gate in the medieval walls. The stone arch gateway borders a view of steps leading up passed residential buildings. Part of St. Michaels church, including it's spire, can be seen in the distance.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/pxl-20210607-103043419-01.jpeg)

items.content_html: Transcendence is a tough prompt, but it always conjures spiritual thoughts in me. So, I’ve had to go back to last year and a trip to Gloucester Cathedral, an incredible building and a true monument to the faith and worship of those who built it.
items.content_text:
**Transcendence** is a tough prompt, but it always conjures spiritual thoughts in me. So, I've had to go back to last year and a trip to [Gloucester Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gloucester_Cathedral), an incredible building and a true monument to the faith and worship of those who built it.

![Intricate masonry of an internal cathedral corner, with windows on each side. The windows are arched and the walls curve into patterned stonework of the ceiling. A curved, almost S shaped, support snakes from lower right to upper left sweeping into the ceiling curve.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/pxl-20230424-102733497-01.jpeg)

items.content_html: The urban pigeon is the very epitome of fl√¢neur. Constantly wandering the streets, aloof and aimless.

Fernando Alonso: Aston Martin driver signs new deal until end of 2026

Fernando Alonso signs a deal to stay with Aston Martin until at least the end of 2026 - keeping him in Formula 1 until he is 45.

items.content_html: Windy day yesterday in West Portholland as we awaited the arrival of storm Kathleen.
items.content_text:
**Windy** day yesterday in [West Portholland](https://www.openstreetmap.org/?mlat=50.23484&mlon=-4.86614#map=18/50.23484/-4.86614) as we awaited the arrival of [storm Kathleen](https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/about-us/press-office/news/weather-and-climate/2024/storm-kathleen-named-and-weather-warnings-issued).

![Waves crash on a small beach in strong winds. The beach is predominantly medium sized bluish grey pebbles, with a large rock formation in the left foreground. In the distance to the left is the Dodman Point headland.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/20240405-portholland-01.jpeg)

items.content_html: Tomorrow we travel home, so day seven is essentially the last day. A visit to the church at St Just in Roseland is a must whenever we’re here. It’s the most peaceful and tranquil place next to a creek and nestled in incredible gardens. The Celts founded a church here in the 6th century, and large parts the current building date back around 800 years. Didn’t manage the walk this year, but the coastal path between St Mawes and the church provides great views over Carrick Roads.
items.content_text:
Tomorrow we travel home, so day seven is essentially the last day. A visit to [the church at St Just in Roseland](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Just%27s_Church,_St_Just_in_Roseland) is a must whenever we're here. It's the most peaceful and tranquil place next to a creek and nestled in incredible gardens. The Celts founded a church here in the 6th century, and large parts the current building date back around 800 years. Didn't manage the walk this year, but the coastal path between St Mawes and the church provides great views over [Carrick Roads](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrick_Roads).

- [![The church at St. Just viewed across a tidal creek. The tide is out and the creek dry. Behind the church the gardens rise up the hill.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-0.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-0.jpeg)
- [![An area of Gunnera manicata, aka giant rhubarb, with large plants in the foreground and smaller plants behind.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-1.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-1.jpeg)
- [![View of the 13th century St Just church showing the bell tower. Gravestones line the edge of the creek to the left.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-2.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-2.jpeg)
- [![Inside the small church of St Just showing aisles of pews and a row of internal supporting arches.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-3.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-3.jpeg)
- [![Stained glass window consisting of three frames depicting Jesus holding a lamb and staff, flanked by a male harpist and male holding a bible verse.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-4.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-4.jpeg)
- [![Staind glass windows consisting of three frames depicting Jesus and (presumably) two saints with doves.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-5.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-5.jpeg)
- [![A pink and yellow primrose with leaves, growing in the gardens of St Just church.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-6.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-6.jpeg)
- [![Close up of a section of wooden door with large keyhole.](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-7.jpeg)](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/10150/2024/2024-04-05-7.jpeg)

items.content_html: Day six brought a quiet morning reading as the rain poured. There was a brief break so we headed down to the harbour for some crabbing, not really my scene. The rain soon returned so I left the ladies to what has become a Cornwall family tradition. We ended the day with a delightful pub meal at The Ship Inn, Portloe. Just one day left…

items.content_html: It’s day five already and, for the most part, the sun shone. We got down to Pendower Beach for a stroll along the water line and a bit of shell hunting before setting off to Melinsey Mill and our first cream tea of the week. Last born was less enamoured with our evening game tonight as she was soundly beaten at Uno by her elders. üòÄ
items.content_text:
It's day five already and, for the most part, the sun shone. We got down to [Pendower Beach](https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/visit/cornwall/carne-and-pendower/explore-the-beaches-at-carne-and-pendower) for a stroll along the water line and a bit of shell hunting before setting off to [Melinsey Mill](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melinsey) and our first cream tea of the week. Last born was less enamoured with our evening game tonight as she was soundly beaten at [Uno](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uno_(card_game)) by her elders. üòÄ

items.content_html: Day four has been the wettest so far, so a pasty lunch above Pendower Beach followed by a quick run to Truro Cathedral were the order of the day. The cathedral is impressive and quite new by catherdral standards, as such it lacked some of the history of others but none of the grandeur. Capped off the day with a quick round of Pass the Pigs and Uno with the last born. First born is frustratingly resistant to most games.
items.content_text:
Day four has been the wettest so far, so a pasty lunch above [Pendower Beach](https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/visit/cornwall/carne-and-pendower/explore-the-beaches-at-carne-and-pendower) followed by a quick run to [Truro Cathedral](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truro_Cathedral) were the order of the day. The cathedral is impressive and quite new by catherdral standards, as such it lacked some of the history of others but none of the grandeur. Capped off the day with a quick round of [Pass the Pigs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pass_the_Pigs) and [Uno](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uno_(card_game)) with the last born. First born is frustratingly resistant to most games.

items.content_html: Somewhat wetter third day, but a great visit to Trelissick, I can happily leave the house, but the surrounding common and woodland, along with the gardens offer fabulous walks and beautiful views over the Fal estuary. A favourite in this part of the world.
items.content_text:
Somewhat wetter third day, but a great visit to [Trelissick](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trelissick), I can happily leave the house, but the surrounding common and woodland, along with the gardens offer fabulous walks and beautiful views over the Fal estuary. A favourite in this part of the world.

items.content_html: Easter Sunday and day 2 on the beautiful Roseland. What other way to start the day than with an egg hunt? Then we headed for a short walk along the banks of the Percuil River before a family card game to end the day. Last born was delighted to beat me at the final count.
items.content_text:
Easter Sunday and day 2 on the beautiful Roseland. What other way to start the day than with an egg hunt? Then we headed for a short walk along the banks of the [Percuil River](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percuil_River) before a family card game to end the day. Last born was delighted to beat me at the final count.

items.content_html: There’s a lot of noise around AI at the moment, and to be honest I struggle to see the value in a lot of it. However, the ability to generate images like this with just a short paragraph of description is a huge help to those like me whose hands cannot recreate what their mind can imagine.

items.content_html: I’m a bit late on this one, but Lewis moving to Ferrari is a fascinating and unexpected (rather than surprising) move. It’s been a story that just won’t go away for a while. The lure of Maranello is as strong as ever it seems, can’t wait to see how it pans out. I really hope they can get on top of the errors that have held them back in recent seasons. Roll on 2025. üèéÔ∏è

Support the Girls - 2024-01-23 - An entertaining look at a day in the life of Regina Hall’s Lisa as she navigates this peculiar corner of American culture. She’s excellent as the mother figure in a story that’s familiar from many similar tellings that have come before. üé¨

The Movie Database

Support the Girls

Lisa Conroy is general manager at a highway-side ‘sports bar with curves’, Double Whammies. She nurtures and protects her employees fiercely - but over the course of one trying day, her optimism is battered from every direction. Double Whammies sells a big, weird American fantasy, but what happens when reality pokes a bunch of holes in it?

The Marvels

Carol Danvers, aka Captain Marvel, has reclaimed her identity from the tyrannical Kree and taken revenge on the Supreme Intelligence. But unintended consequences see Carol shouldering the burden of a destabilized universe. When her duties send her to an anomalous wormhole linked to a Kree revolutionary, her powers become entangled with that of Jersey City super-fan Kamala Khan, aka Ms. Marvel, and Carol‚Äôs estranged niece, now S.A.B.E.R. astronaut Captain Monica Rambeau. Together, this unlikely trio must team up and learn to work in concert to save the universe.

items.content_html:
The Hunger Games - 2023-11-21 - It’s not a masterpiece, but it is great fun - possibly nostalgia talking. I’ve seen this so many times now and it’s always both brutal and moving. It triggered a rush of inferior YA adaptations and, despite its flaws, it’s still better than a lot of the competition. Youngest Daughter is desperate to watch it, so it’ll probably be on again very soon. üé¨

The Movie Database

The Hunger Games

Every year in the ruins of what was once North America, the nation of Panem forces each of its twelve districts to send a teenage boy and girl to compete in the Hunger Games. Part twisted entertainment, part government intimidation tactic, the Hunger Games are a nationally televised event in which ‚ÄúTributes‚Äù must fight with one another until one survivor remains. Pitted against highly-trained Tributes who have prepared for these Games their entire lives, Katniss is forced to rely upon her sharp instincts as well as the mentorship of drunken former victor Haymitch Abernathy. If she‚Äôs ever to return home to District 12, Katniss must make impossible choices in the arena that weigh survival against humanity and life against love. The world will be watching.

Hard Feelings - 2023-10-23 - Being honest, watching this was a mistake. Not because it’s bad, but I was looking for something else and not paying attention. I was confronted with an unexpected German sex comedy. It’s a novel idea with a largely predictable story arc whose main joke does eventually wear a little thin. There are some glimmers of real insight in there into just how cruel those teenage years can be. üé¨

The ability of a man to steal the attention away from the achievements of Spain’s women should be surprising. Sadly, it’s not. Even with the vast strides being made in the women’s game, this serves as a stark reminder that there are still idiots at the highest levels looking to take advantage. I look forward to the day we can celebrate these kinds of successes without entitled idiots stealing the narrative.

Hopefully, strong condemnation from all areas of the game, and this principled stand from the team will force the necessary change, and drive better representation. ‚öΩ

items.content_html:
Incredibly proud of Child 1 today as she collects her GCSE results. School life, and Secondary School life in particular, have been a real challenge for her. For all of us. However, she’s battled through the stress, the tears, and the challenges and come out a young lady with a good set of qualifications and a positive future.

As important as academic achievement is we’ve always asked her to focus on hard work, good manners, and kindness. She’s managed that in the face of almost constant headwinds and has been rewarded for her efforts. Her results comfortably allow her to move on with her next adventure. Now, we have just around 10 days before she starts that new journey 111 miles away. It’s going to be an emotional couple of weeks…

items.content_html: There are worse views to wake up to in the morning. The imposing Corfe Castle in Dorset. Even as a ruin it’s an incredible building to explore. In its full finery it must have been an incredible place.

items.content_html:
Barbie - 2023-08-03 - Terrifically entertaining and very funny. Some parts are better than others, but overall a really good job of walking the complex tightrope of thoughts and emotions that surround what is, for better or worse, a cultural icon. Beautifully scripted and led by the ever impressive Margot Robbie, it’s well worth a watch. I suspect I’ll be seeing it again with the family in a few weeks.

items.content_html:
See How They Run - 2023-08-01 - Saoirse Ronan is endlessly watchable in absolutely anything and her presence here elevates this light-hearted and lightweight comedy spoof in the way that she elevates everything. An enjoyable, and probably rewatchable couple of hours.

The Movie Database

See How They Run

In the West End of 1950s London, plans for a movie version of a smash-hit play come to an abrupt halt after a pivotal member of the crew is murdered. When world-weary Inspector Stoppard and eager rookie Constable Stalker take on the case, the two find themselves thrown into a puzzling whodunit within the glamorously sordid theatre underground, investigating the mysterious homicide at their own peril.

items.content_html:
Oppenheimer - 2023-07-30 - Undeniably Nolan, and remarkably visual for a film filled with men talking in rooms and looking at the New Mexico desert. Oppenheimer deals in theoretical physics, sub-atomic particles, political ideology and moral quandary - and somehow makes it all visible. There’s a lot of threads here, but we’re given a vision of a man holding the universe’s smallest particles and the world greatest questions in his mind at the same time.

This isn’t Nolan’s very best, but it is very good.

The Movie Database

Oppenheimer

The story of J. Robert Oppenheimer‚Äôs role in the development of the atomic bomb during World War II.
